thread.title: North-east gains £1.35bn devolution deals

title: North-east gains £1.35bn devolution deals
text:
HMRC fights back against company tax claims 
Despite the focus on growth, however, the business community fears being sidelined by Labour, which dominates politics in the region. 
“Devolution is all about a shared sense of ownership; I think we need a change of the mood music with business,” said Charlie Hoult, a Newcastle businessman and leading figure in the north-east’s digital sector. 
Jonathan Walker, head of policy and campaigns for the North East Chamber of Commerce, welcomed the deals. But he added: “Devolution to the region will only be successful if it involves broad and effective engagement with business, and we expect meaningful conversations to begin on this matter as soon as possible.” 
The deals, which cover the North East Combined Authority area and Tees Valley, are expected to prove controversial among many in the Labour party as they require the creation of elected mayors. 
Nick Brown, the Labour MP for Newcastle East and a former minister for the north-east, called for the ballot paper in a future mayoral election to offer the option to vote “No”. He dismissed the move as “a lot of talk and no effective action”. 
“The power to borrow more money and to tax ourselves more isn’t what is needed to solve the problems that the region faces — above all, the need to stimulate private sector investment in the north-east of England,” he said. 
Tortuous negotiations to achieve the deals, particularly in the North East Combined Authority area, have also highlighted the difficulty of agreeing radical change. In 2004, the north-east voted overwhelmingly in a referendum to reject a regional assembly, with voters fearing that it would merely be an expensive talking shop. 
The region’s experience of elected mayors has been mixed; it currently has two — in North Tyneside and Middlesbrough — but Hartlepool scrapped the system. Related Topics
